page.title: 04WOODLAND VEGETATION
page.content: About 10% of the area surveyed consisted of open woodland. Much of it (about 75%) showed signs of coppicing. Between every 8-25 years the growth is cut and then allowed to shoot again from the stumps. The most common species observed were Sweet Chestnut, Hornbeam and Hazel(especially in Trenley Park Wood). Sweet Chestnut is used for fencing but the market for coppice timber is less important now. Larger trees known as standards are grown in between the coppiced trees. This is designed to give well spaced oaks room to develop and spread. Some farmers now cut chestnut fencing for themselves and sell the surplus as hop poles and fruit stakes. Some woodland areas seemed to be neglected with several unculled dead and fallen trees
